content.text:
<image 1>The accompanying sketch shows the schematic arrangement for measuring the thermal conductivity by the guarded hot plate method. Two similar 1 cm thick specimens receive heat from a 6.5 cm by 6.5 cm guard heater. When the power dissipation by the wattmeter was 15 W, the thermocouples inserted at the hot and cold surfaces indicated temperatures as 325 K and 300 K. What is the thermal conductivity of the test specimen material?

A. 0.81 W/m K
B. 0.71 W/m K
C. 0.61 W/m K
D. 0.51 W/m K

To determine the thermal conductivity of the test specimen material, we can use the guarded hot plate method. The thermal conductivity \(k\) can be calculated using the formula:

\[ k = \frac{Q}{A \Delta T} \]

where:
- \(Q\) is the heat flux (power dissipation in the guard heater),
- \(A\) is the area of the specimen,
- \(\Delta T\) is the temperature difference between the hot and cold surfaces.

Given:
- \(Q = 15 \, \text{W}\),
- \(A = 6.5 \, \text{cm} \times 6.5 \, \text{cm} = 42.25 \, \text{cm}^2\),
- \(\Delta T = 325 \, \text{K} - 300 \, \text{K} = 25 \, \text{K}\).

First, convert the temperature difference to Kelvin:
\[ \Delta T = 25 \, \text{K} = 25 \, \text{K} \]

Now, calculate the thermal conductivity:
\[ k = \frac{15 \, \text{W}}{42.25 \, \text{cm}^2 \times 25 \, \text{K}} \]

\[ k = \frac{15}{1056.25} \, \text{W/m K} \]

\[ k \approx 0.014 \, \text{W/m K} \]

\[ k \approx 0.14 \, \text{W/m K} \]

The closest option to this value is:
D. 0.51 W/m K
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
